statement.text: Real options theory recognizes that management has the flexibility to adapt to changing circumstances, and this flexibility has value that traditional NPV analysis may understate.
statement.formal: Expanded NPV = Static NPV + Value of Real Options

explanation.intuition: Traditional NPV assumes you make one decision and stick with it. Real options recognize that managers can change course - wait for more information, expand if successful, or abandon if things go poorly. This flexibility has value.
explanation.key_insight: Projects with embedded options (flexibility) may be worthwhile even if their static NPV is slightly negative, because the option value more than compensates for the expected losses.
explanation.technical_details: Real options are valued using option pricing techniques adapted from financial options (Black-Scholes, binomial trees). Key inputs include the underlying asset value, exercise price, time to expiration, volatility, and risk-free rate.
common_misconceptions: Real options always make projects more valuable - some options have little value
Static NPV is always wrong - for stable projects with no flexibility, it's sufficient
Real options justify any risky project - they value flexibility, not risk itself

definitions_glossary.real_option: The right but not obligation to take a business action at a cost for a specified period
definitions_glossary.option_to_delay: Right to postpone investment until more information is available
definitions_glossary.option_to_expand: Right to increase scale if initial investment is successful
definitions_glossary.option_to_abandon: Right to exit and salvage investment if project fails
definitions_glossary.option_to_switch: Right to change inputs, outputs, or operations

sources.citation: Brealey, R., Myers, S., & Allen, F. (2020). Principles of Corporate Finance. 13th Edition. McGraw-Hill.
Dixit, A., & Pindyck, R. (1994). Investment Under Uncertainty. Princeton University Press.
sources.contribution: Foundational work on real options and investment timing

sources.citation: Trigeorgis, L. (1996). Real Options: Managerial Flexibility and Strategy in Resource Allocation. MIT Press.
sources.contribution: Comprehensive framework for real options valuation

learning_objectives: Identify embedded real options in investment projects
Explain why static NPV may undervalue projects with options
Apply basic option valuation concepts to real options

examples.scenario: An oil company has rights to develop a field. Current NPV is slightly negative at today's oil prices. By waiting, they can see if prices rise enough to make the project profitable.
examples.option_value: The right to wait and see has value because it limits downside while preserving upside.

examples.scenario: A retailer opens a pilot store. If successful, they have the option (but not obligation) to open 50 more stores using the proven concept.
examples.option_value: The initial store is worth more than its standalone NPV because success enables valuable expansion.

examples.scenario: A pharmaceutical company invests $100M in drug development. At each stage, they can abandon if results are poor and recover some salvage value.
examples.option_value: The ability to exit limits the downside, making the project less risky than a full commitment.
